question: Question 208 In the op-amp circuit given in the figure, the load current [latex]i_{L}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V}{R_{2}}+\frac{V}{R_{L}}+\frac{V}{R_{2}}&=\frac{V_{0}}{R_{2}} \\ \frac{2 V}{R_{2}}+\frac{V}{R_{L}}&=\frac{V_{0}}{R_{2}} &\ldots(i)\\ \frac{V_{s}-V}{R_{1}}&=\frac{V-V_{0}}{R_{1}} \\ V_{s}-2 V&=-V_{0} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{Putting } V_{o} \text{ from (i)},\\ \frac{-V_{s}+2 V}{R_{2}} &=+\left(\frac{2 V}{R_{2}}+\frac{V}{R_{L}}\right) \\ i_{L} &=\frac{V}{R_{L}}=-\frac{V_{S}}{R_{2}}=\left[\frac{V}{R_{L}}=i_{L}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 209 The value of C required for sinusoidal oscillations of frequency 1 kHz in the circuit of the figure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R &=1 \mathrm{k} \\ \frac{V_{o}-V_{1}}{X_{C}+R} &=\frac{V_{1}}{X_{C}}+\frac{V_{1}}{R} \\ \frac{V_{o}-V_{1}}{X_{C}+R} &=V_{1}\left(\frac{X_{C}+R}{X_{C} \cdot R}\right) \\ \frac{V_{o}}{V_{1}} &=\frac{\left(X_{C}+R\right)^{2}}{X_{C} \cdot R}+1 \quad\left[X_{C}=-\frac{j}{\omega C}\right] \\ \frac{V_{o}}{V_{1}} &=\frac{-\frac{1}{\omega^{2} C^{2}}+R^{2}-\frac{2 j R}{\omega C}}{\frac{R}{j \omega C}}+1 \\ \frac{V_{0}}{V_{1}} &=+\frac{j \omega C}{R}\left(-\frac{1}{\omega^{2} C^{2}}+R^{2}-\frac{2 j R}{\omega C}\right)+1 \end{aligned}[/latex] For oscillation imaginary part is zero. i.e. [latex]j\left[\frac{\omega C}{R} \times \frac{-1}{\omega^{2} C^{2}}+\frac{\omega C}{R} \times R^{2}\right]=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{-1}{\omega C A}+\omega C R&=0\\ \omega^{2} C^{2} R^{2}-1&=0 \\ \omega^{2}&=\frac{1}{R^{2} C^{2}} \\ C&=\frac{1}{\omega R}=\frac{1}{2 \pi \times 10^{3} \times 10^{3}} \\ C&=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 210 A bipolar transistor is operating in the active region with a collector current of 1 mA. Assuming that the [latex]\beta[/latex] of the transistor is 100 and the thermal voltage ([latex]V_{T}[/latex]) is 25 mV, the transconductance ([latex]g_{m}[/latex]) and the input resistance ([latex]r_{\pi}[/latex]) of the transistor in the common emitter configuration, are
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} g_{m}=\frac{I_{C}}{V_{T}}=\frac{1 \mathrm{mA}}{25 \mathrm{mV}}=0.04=40 \mathrm{mAV} \\ h_{\mathrm{fe}}=g_{m} \cdot r_{\pi}, h_{\mathrm{fe}}=\beta \\ r_{\pi}=\frac{\beta}{g_{m}}=\frac{100}{40 \times 10^{-3}}=2.5 \mathrm{k} \Omega \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 211 Assume that the [latex]\beta[/latex] of transistor is extremely large and [latex]V_{BE}[/latex] = 0.7V, [latex]I_{C}[/latex] and [latex]V_{CE}[/latex] in the circuit shown in the figure are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{Th}&=\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}R_{2}}V_{C C}=\frac{1}{5} \times 5=1\\ R_{Th}&=R_{1} \| R_{2}=\frac{4}{5} k \Omega\\ I_{C}&\simeq \frac{1}{0.3 k \Omega}=1 \mathrm{mA}\left(\because \beta \text { is large } I_{B} \simeq 0\right)\\ V_{CE}&=V_{C C}-I_{C} R_{C}-I_{E} R_{E}\left(I_{E}=I_{C}\text { as } \right. \\ V_{CE}&=5-2.2 \times 1-0.3 \times 1 \\ V_{CE}&=2.5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 216 Three identical amplifiers with each one having a voltage gain of 50, input resistance of 1 k[latex]\Omega[/latex] and output resistance of 250 [latex]\Omega[/latex] are cascaded. The opened circuit voltages gain of the combined amplifier is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \quad A_{v}=\frac{V_{4}}{V_{1}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad A_{v}=\frac{V_{4}}{V_{3}} \times \frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}} \times \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \end{array}[/latex] Voltage across 1k after 1 st stage is, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{2}&=\frac{1000 \times 50 V_{1}}{1250}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}&=40\\ \text{Similarly }\frac{V_{3}}{V_{2}}&=40 \\ \therefore \quad A_{v}&=40 \times 40 \times 50=8 \times 10^{4} \\ A_{v} \text { in }(\mathrm{dB})&=20 \log \left(8 \times 10^{4}\right)=98 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 221 In the amplifier circuit shown in the figure, the values of [latex]R_{1}[/latex] and [latex]R_{2}[/latex] are such that the transistor is operating at [latex]V_{CE}[/latex] = 3 V and [latex]I_{C}[/latex] = 1.5 mA when its [latex]\beta[/latex] is 150. For a transistor with [latex]\beta[/latex] of 200, the operating point ([latex]V_{CE}[/latex], [latex]I_{C}[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{C E} &=V_{C C}-I_{C} R_{2} \\ 3 &=6-1.5 \mathrm{mA} \times R_{2} \\ 1.5 \mathrm{mA} \times \mathrm{R}_{2}&=3 \\ R_{2} &=2 \mathrm{k} \Omega \\ I_{B} &=\frac{I_{C}}{\beta}=\frac{1.5 \mathrm{mA}}{150}=0.01 \mathrm{mA} \\ \text { When } \beta&=200 \\ I_{C} &=\beta I_{B}\\ &\left(\text{as} R_{1} \text { is same } I_{B} \text{ remains same }\right)\\ &=0.01 \mathrm{mA} \times 200\\ I_{C} &=2 \mathrm{mA} \\ V_{C E} &=V_{C C}-I_{C} R_{2}=6-2 \mathrm{mA} \times 2 \mathrm{K} 2 \\ V_{C E} &=2 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 222 An amplifier without feedback has a voltage gain of 50, input resistance of 1 k[latex]\Omega[/latex] and output resistance of 2.5 k[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The input resistance of the current-shunt negative feedback amplifier using the above amplifier with a feedback factor of 0.2, is
solution: In current shunt negative feedback amplifier. [latex] R_{i f}=\frac{R_{i}}{1+A \beta} ; R_{i f}=\frac{1 \times 10^{3}}{1+50 \times 0.2}=\frac{10^{3}}{1+10} [/latex] [latex] R_{i f}=\frac{1}{11} k \Omega[/latex]

Question 224 If the differential voltage gain and the common mode voltage gain of a differential amplifier are 48 dB and 2 dB respectively, then common mode rejection ratio is

question: Question 225 If the input to the ideal comparators shown in the figure is a sinusoidal signal of 8 V (peak to peak) without any DC component, then the output of the comparators has a duty cycle of
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{p-p}&=8 V\\ \text{So,} \quad V_{i}&=4 \sin \omega t \\ \text { At } \quad V_{i}&=2 \\ \sin \omega t &=\frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \omega t&=\frac{\pi}{6} \end{aligned}[/latex] Another crossover at [latex]\pi-\frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{5 \pi}{6} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \text { Duty cycle }=\frac{T_{\text {on }}}{T}=\frac{\frac{5 \pi}{6}-\frac{\pi}{6}}{2 \pi}=\frac{\left(\frac{4 \pi}{6}\right)}{2 \pi}= \frac{1}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 229 The voltage gain [latex]A\Delta =\frac{V_{o}}{V_{i}}[/latex] of the JFET amplifier shown in figure 2.8 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g_{m} &=\frac{2 I_{D S S}}{\left|V_{P}\right|}\left(1-\frac{V_{G S}}{V_{P}}\right) \\ V_{G} &=0, V_{S}=I_{D} \cdot R_{S}=1 \mathrm{mA} \times 2.5 \\ V_{s} &=2.5 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{G S} &=V_{G}-V_{S}=-2.5 \mathrm{V} \\ g_{m} &=\frac{2 \times 10 \mathrm{mA}}{5}\left(1-\left(\frac{-2.5}{-5}\right)\right)=2 \mathrm{mS} \\ A_{v} &=-g_{m} R_{D} \\ &\quad \left(\because r_{d} \text { is not given, it is taken as } \infty\right) \\ &=-2 m S \times 3 k \Omega=-6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 230 A zener diode regulator in figure  is to be designed to meet the specifications:
[latex]I_{L}=10mA, \; V_{0}=10V[/latex] and [latex]V_{in}[/latex] varies from 30 V to 50 V. The zener diode has
[latex]V_{Z}[/latex] = 10V and [latex]I_{ZK}[/latex] (knee current) = 1 mA. For satisfactory opertion
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{\text {in }}-V_{o}}{R} &\geq I_{Z}+I_{L} \\ \text { when } \quad V_{\text {in }}&=30 \mathrm{V} \\ \frac{30-10}{R} &\geq(10+1) \mathrm{mA} \\ \frac{20}{R} &\geq 11 \mathrm{mA} \\ \Rightarrow \quad R &\leq 1818 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 231 The circuit in figure employs positive feedback and is intended to generate
sinusoidal oscillation. If at a frequency [latex]f_{0}B(f)=\Delta \frac{V_{f}}{V_{0}}=\frac{1}{6}\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex], then to sustain oscillation at this frequency
solution: KCL at node 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\beta V_{o}-0}{R_{1}}+\frac{\beta V_{o}-V_{o}}{R_{2}} &=0 \\ \beta\left(\frac{1}{R_{1}}+\frac{1}{R_{2}}\right) &=\frac{1}{R_{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad \beta \cdot \frac{R_{1}+R_{2}}{R_{1}} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad\frac{R_{1}\left(1+\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\right)}{R_{1}} &=\frac{1}{\beta}=6 \\ \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}} &=5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad R_{2} &=5 R_{1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 232 An amplifier using an opamp with a slew-rate SR = 1V/[latex]\mu[/latex] sec has a gain of 40 dB.
If this amplifier has to faithfully amplify sinusoidal signals from dc to 20 KHz
without introducing any slew-rate induced distortion, then the input signal level
must not exceed.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Slew rate } &=A \cdot 2 \pi f V_{m} \\ V &=A V_{m} \sin \omega t \\ \frac{d V}{d t} &=A V_{m} \omega \cos \omega t \\ \left.\frac{d V}{d t}\right|_{\max } &=S R=A V_{m} 2 \pi f_{m} \\ 20 \log x &=40 \\ x &=100=A \\ \Rightarrow V_{m}=\frac{S R}{A \cdot 2 \pi f_{m}} &=\frac{1}{10^{-6} \times 100 \times 2 \pi \times 20 \times 10^{3}} \\ V_{m} &=79.5 \mathrm{mV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 237 In figure, assume the OP-AMPs to be ideal. The output [latex]V_{o}[/latex]
 of the circuit is:
solution: KCL at node 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{2}}{V_{s}} &=\frac{-\omega L}{R} \\ &=\frac{-100 \times 10 \times 10^{-3}}{10}=-\frac{1}{10} \\ V_{2} &=-\frac{V_{s}}{10}=-\cos 100 t\\ \frac{V_{0}}{V_{2}} &=\frac{-1 / \omega \mathrm{c}}{100} \\ &=-\frac{1}{100 \times 10 \times 10^{-6} \times 100}=-10 \\ V_{0} &=-10 \mathrm{V}_{2}=-10(-\cos 100 \mathrm{t}) \\ V_{0} &=10 \cos 100 \mathrm{t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 238 The inverting OP-AMP shown in figure has an open-loop gain of 100. The
closed loop gain [latex]\frac{V_{o}}{V_{s}}[/latex] is
solution: If open loop gain is not infinite, then [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{\beta} &=-\frac{R_{f}}{R_{1}}=-\frac{10 \mathrm{k}}{1 \mathrm{k}}=-10 \\ |\beta| &=\frac{1}{10} \\ A_{f} &=\frac{-A}{1+A \beta}=\frac{-100}{1+100 \times \frac{1}{10}}=-\frac{100}{11} \\ A_{f} & \cong-9 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 240 The transistor shunt regulator
shown in figure has a
regulated output voltage of 10
V, when the input varies from
20 V to 30 V. The relevant
parameters for the Zener diode
and the transistor are: [latex]V_{Z}[/latex]
=9.5,[latex]V_{SE}[/latex] =0.3V, [latex]\beta[/latex]
=99. Neglect
the current through [latex]R_{B}[/latex]. Then
the maximum power dissipated
in the Zener diode ([latex]P_{Z}[/latex]) and the
transistor ([latex]P_{T}[/latex]) are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{1 \max }&=\frac{V_{\text {in } \max }-V_{O}}{20}\\ I_{1} &=\frac{30-10}{20}=1 \mathrm{A} \quad \text { (i.e. when } I_{Z}=0) \\ I_{E} &=I_{C}+I_{Z} &\ldots(i)\\ I_{B} &=I_{Z}\left(\text { as no current flows in } R_{B}\text { ) } \right.\\ \beta &=\frac{I_{C}}{I_{B}}=\frac{I_{C}}{I_{Z}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad I_{C} &=\beta I_{Z} \\ \text { From (i) }, I_{E} &=\beta I_{Z}+I_{Z}=(99+1) I_{Z} \\ I_{E} &=100 I_{Z} \\ I_{1} &=I_{E}=100 I_{Z} \\ I_{Z} &=\frac{I_{1}}{100}=\frac{1}{100}=0.01 \mathrm{A} \\ P_{Z} &=V_{Z} I_{Z}=9.5 \times 0.01=95 \mathrm{mW} \\ I_{C} &=99 I_{Z}=99 \times 0.01=0.99 \mathrm{A} \\ P_{C} &=V_{C} I_{C}=10 \times 0.99=9.9 \mathrm{W}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 241 An npn BJT has [latex]g_{m}=38m\, A/V[/latex], [latex]C_{\mu }=10^{-14}\,F[/latex],[latex]C_{\pi }=4\times 10^{-13}\,F[/latex]
 and DC current gain [latex]\beta _{0}=90[/latex]. For this transistor  [latex]f_{T}[/latex]and [latex]f_{\beta }[/latex] are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{T} &=\frac{g_{m}}{2 \pi\left(C_{\mu}+C_{\pi}\right)} \\ &=\frac{38 \times 10^{-3}}{2 \pi \times\left(10^{-14}+4 \times 10^{-13}\right)} \\ &=\frac{38 \times 10^{-3}}{2 \pi \times 10^{-13}(0.1+4)}=1.47 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{Hz} \\ &=\frac{f_{T}}{\beta_{0}}=\frac{1.47 \times 10^{10}}{90} \\ &=1.64 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{Hz} \quad&\left(\beta_{0}=h_{1}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]
